subject: history
title: European Arrival in India: Timeline
description: Chronological discovery of sea routes and establishment of European powers in India

events.title: Fall of Constantinople
events.description: Ottoman Turks captured Constantinople, blocking land route

points: Byzantine Empire fell to Ottoman Turks
Traditional land route to India blocked
Increased urgency to find sea route
details.significance: Triggered European search for alternative routes to India

events.title: Discovery of Cape of Good Hope
events.description: Bartholomew Diaz reached southern tip of Africa

points: Reached and rounded Cape of Good Hope
Proved sea route to India possible
Renamed by Portuguese King John II
details.significance: Proved feasibility of reaching India by sea via African route

events.title: Vasco da Gama Reaches India
events.description: First European to reach India by sea via Cape of Good Hope

points: Guided by Arab navigator Ahmad ibn Majid
Returned to Portugal with spices in 1499
details.significance: Historic moment - opened direct sea route to India; beginning of European colonialism

events.title: Portuguese Establish Factories
events.description: First trading posts established on Indian coast

points: Friendly relations with local rulers initially
details.significance: First permanent European presence in India

events.title: Portuguese Capture Goa
events.description: Alfonso de Albuquerque captured Goa from Sultan of Bijapur

points: Captured from Sultan Yusuf Adil Shah of Bijapur
details.significance: Established Portuguese territorial control; Goa became Asian headquarters
Consolidated Portuguese control over western Indian Ocean trade

events.title: Dutch Enter Indian Trade
events.description: Dutch expeditions and formation of VOC

points: First Dutch voyage by Cornelis de Houtman (1595)
United East India Company (VOC) formed in 1602
Given monopoly of Dutch trade east of Cape
details.significance: Introduced corporate structure; challenged Portuguese monopoly

points: Officially: 'Governor and Company of Merchants of London Trading into the East Indies'
15-year monopoly on English trade with East
First voyage led by James Lancaster (1601)
details.significance: Beginning of English involvement in India; eventually became ruling power

points: Captain William Hawkins visited Jahangir's court (1608)
Failed to get trading rights initially
Sir Thomas Roe as James I's ambassador (1615-1619)
details.significance: Established English foothold in Mughal India; beginning of diplomatic relations

points: Given monopoly of French trade with East
details.significance: France enters competition for Indian trade

events.title: English Acquire Bombay
events.description: Portuguese princess's dowry to Charles II

points: Part of Catherine of Braganza's dowry
Marriage to Charles II of England
Given to East India Company in 1668
Shifted headquarters from Surat to Bombay (1687)
details.significance: Gave English strategic island fortress; became presidency capital

points: Fran√ßois Dupleix later made it powerful
details.significance: Became center of French power in India
Became most important English settlement; future capital of British India

events.title: English Establish Madras
events.description: Francis Day obtained grant for Madras

points: Francis Day and Andrew Cogan obtained land
From local ruler Damarla Venkatadri Nayaka
details.significance: First fortified English settlement; important presidency

events.title: Battle of Plassey
events.description: English victory over Nawab of Bengal; beginning of political power

points: Marked beginning of British political power
details.significance: Watershed moment - transformed English from traders to political power
